title: Local app
description: Create a local Electron+React app to handle project management, see tasks and feature status, update task fields/notes, see all the documents in a nice Markdown display, be able to launch/manage agents running locally and overview status in git (i.e. being able to see if an agent is working on something or not), getting notifications when work is done etc., see all child projects and manage them in the future. Ideally this app is the go-to place for anyone to use THIS project (the factory) and wouldn't have to run any scripts or code manually. A big feature of this should also be access to some sort of chat interface so that it should be possible to talk with a chosen LLM about the whole project. It should be possible to give the LLM chat access to the same tools that the agents use but in a restricted manner, so only the ones that are read-only. It should also be possible to configure further ways of connecting to LLMS for chat and for agents other than the currently chosen litellm. For instance, there's an app LM Studio that allows connecting to a locally running LLM via API calls. The project for the local app exists detailing the steps involved in creating a local app for project management. This will be the first project to stem from this one. It should follow the same exact principles as this project, but it will live in its own separate repository. This project is just meant to kickstart the whole scaffolding and specification. If any extra functionality comes into this project, it should be easy to adapt this Local app project to use the exact same ideas. Notes: Currently I'm using VSCode to view the project, run everything, see tasks etc. It would be ideal to have a dedicated app for managing the project, viewing tasks, seeing progress etc. For being able to see how the agents fares etc. Cline the plugin for VSCode does something like this and maybe it makes sense to even built upon a fork on this. One thing to keep in mind is that we want to be really third-party independent. If we can create something ourselves we should. The only question is how it integrates with the project. If maintaining such a service/dependency is too heavy, then using a third party solution makes sense. Each third party solution should be its own tasks, with documented features and explanations as to why it was chosen etc.

features.title: Bootstrap Local App repository and add as submodule
features.description: Create a new repository (e.g., factory-local-app) initialized with standard files (README with scope/goals, LICENSE, .gitignore, .editorconfig, .nvmrc, package.json), docs/ folder with placeholders (ARCHITECTURE.md, DEVELOPMENT.md), and minimal Node project setup. Add it to this factory repo as a Git submodule under projects/local-app. Acceptance: submodule exists under projects/local-app; repo contains the specified files; README explains project purpose and alignment to the factory; dev install command and dev script stub documented.
features.plan:
Implementation plan for 5.1: Bootstrap Local App repository and add as submodule

1) Create the remote repository
- Name: factory-local-app (or similar)
- Description: "Local Electron+React app scaffold for project/agent management aligned with the Factory."
- Visibility: per project policy (public/private)
- Default branch: main
- License: MIT (add license file in repo)

2) Initialize the repository locally
- Prepare a working directory and initialize git:
  - git clone <new_repo_url> factory-local-app
  - cd factory-local-app
- Initialize Node version via .nvmrc (use current LTS used by the factory; example below)

3) Create initial file/folder structure
- Root files:
  - README.md
  - LICENSE
  - .gitignore
  - .editorconfig
  - .nvmrc
  - package.json
- Folders:
  - docs/
    - ARCHITECTURE.md
    - DEVELOPMENT.md
  - src/
    - index.js

4) Populate files with minimal, acceptance-compliant content
- README.md (must explain project purpose, alignment with the factory, and have install/dev script docs)
  Suggested content:
  Title: Factory Local App
  Purpose: A local Electron+React app to manage Factory projects, tasks, agent status, documents (Markdown), notifications, and chat with LLMs via read-only tools. This repo is the standalone implementation aligned with the Factory principles.
  Alignment: Shares architecture and conventions with the Factory; intended to integrate seamlessly and evolve independently while remaining compatible with Factory workflows and tooling.
  Status: Bootstrap scaffold only; Electron/React wiring to follow in subsequent features.
  Requirements: Node (see .nvmrc), npm.
  Install: npm install
  Develop: npm run dev (currently a stub that logs a message; see docs/DEVELOPMENT.md)
  Next steps: Electron-React scaffolding, agent read-only tool adapters, LLM provider adapters (LiteLLM, LM Studio, etc.).

- LICENSE: Standard MIT text with your name/year.

- .gitignore (Node + OS/editor basics):
  node_modules/
  dist/
  .DS_Store
  .env
  .env.*
  npm-debug.log*
  yarn-debug.log*
  yarn-error.log*
  .vscode/

- .editorconfig (common defaults):
  root = true

  [*]
  charset = utf-8
  end_of_line = lf
  insert_final_newline = true
  indent_style = space
  indent_size = 2
  trim_trailing_whitespace = true

- .nvmrc: set Node LTS (example):
  20.17.0

- package.json (minimal Node project setup with a dev script stub):
  {
    "name": "@factory/local-app",
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "private": true,
    "description": "Local Electron+React app scaffold for Factory project management.",
    "license": "MIT",
    "type": "module",
    "engines": { "node": ">=20.17.0" },
    "scripts": {
      "dev": "node src/index.js",
      "validate": "node -e \"console.log('TODO: add validation/linting')\""
    }
  }

- docs/ARCHITECTURE.md (placeholder):
  Overview: High-level goals (project/task/agent management UI, docs viewer, notifications, LLM chat with read-only tool access).
  Principles: Local-first, third-party independent when practical; modular adapters for LLM providers; alignment with Factory repo conventions.
  Modules (planned): UI (Electron+React), Data layer (reads project files/git), Agent status integration, LLM provider adapters.
  Security/Privacy: Local data, restricted read-only tool invocation for chat.

- docs/DEVELOPMENT.md (placeholder):
  Prerequisites: Node per .nvmrc, npm, git.
  Setup: nvm use; npm install.
  Commands: npm run dev (currently prints a stub message); npm run validate.
  Conventions: Editorconfig, future lint/formatting planned.
  Next: Add Electron+React scaffolding and dev runner; document environment variables when introduced.

- src/index.js (stub dev entry):
  console.log("Factory Local App: dev environment not yet implemented. See docs/DEVELOPMENT.md.");
  process.exit(0);

5) Commit and push the bootstrap
- git add .
- git commit -m "chore: bootstrap factory-local-app scaffold (docs, config, dev stub)"
- git push origin main

6) Add as a submodule in the Factory repo
- From the root of the Factory repo:
  - git submodule add -b main <new_repo_url> projects/local-app
  - git commit -m "chore(projects): add local app as git submodule"
- If submodules are already initialized, ensure they are updated:
  - git submodule update --init --recursive

7) Verify acceptance criteria
- Submodule exists under projects/local-app pointing to the new repo.
- The submodule's repo contains: README.md, LICENSE, .gitignore, .editorconfig, .nvmrc, package.json, docs/ARCHITECTURE.md, docs/DEVELOPMENT.md, src/index.js.
- README explains project purpose and alignment to Factory and documents install and dev script stub (npm install; npm run dev).

8) Notes and considerations
- Keep this repo independent; future work will add Electron+React and adapter architecture.
- Third-party integrations (LiteLLM, LM Studio, etc.) will be evaluated and documented as separate tasks with rationale.
- Ensure Node version stays in sync with the Factory by updating .nvmrc as needed.

features.title: Electron + React + TypeScript scaffold
features.description: Initialize the app using a modern toolchain (electron-vite with React + TypeScript). Include scripts: dev, build, lint, format. Ensure secure defaults: contextIsolation=true, sandbox where applicable, separate main, preload, and renderer packages. Acceptance: `pnpm/npm run dev` runs the app with React UI placeholder; `... build` yields a runnable app in dist; TypeScript config present; eslint/prettier configured.
features.plan:
Implementation Plan: Electron + React + TypeScript Scaffold using electron-vite

1) Prerequisites and Repo Setup
   1. Ensure Node.js >= 18 and pnpm or npm installed.
   2. Create a new, separate repository for the Local App (e.g., repo name: factory-local-app). Initialize git.
   3. Add a .gitignore (Node + macOS/Windows defaults). Optionally add .nvmrc/.node-version.

2) Scaffold with electron-vite (React + TypeScript)
   1. Run the official scaffolder:
      - Using npm: npm create electron-vite@latest
      - Using pnpm: pnpm dlx create-electron-vite
   2. When prompted:
      - Project name: factory-local-app
      - Framework: React
      - Variant: TypeScript
   3. cd factory-local-app and install deps:
      - pnpm install (or npm install)

3) Verify Project Structure (separate main/preload/renderer)
   1. Ensure folders exist (names may vary by template):
      - electron/main (or src/main): Electron main process
      - electron/preload (or src/preload): Preload scripts
      - src/renderer (or src/renderer): React renderer
   2. Confirm tsconfig(s) exist in root and for sub-packages (if template provides separate ones).

4) Secure BrowserWindow Defaults
   1. Open main process entry (e.g., electron/main/index.ts or src/main/index.ts):
      - In new BrowserWindow({ webPreferences: {...} }) set:
        - preload: path to preload script (resolved with fileURLToPath or join)...
        - sandbox: true
        - contextIsolation: true
        - nodeIntegration: false
        - webSecurity: true
        - devTools: process.env.NODE_ENV !== 'production'
        - disableBlinkFeatures: 'Auxclick' (optional)
      - Remove/disable any use of the remote module.
   2. Handle a simple IPC for testing:
      - ipcMain.handle('ping', () => 'pong')

5) Preload: Minimal, Read-Only, Context Bridge
   1. In preload (e.g., electron/preload/index.ts):
      - import { contextBridge, ipcRenderer } from 'electron'
      - Expose a safe API:
        contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld('api', {
          ping: () => ipcRenderer.invoke('ping'),
          versions: { electron: process.versions.electron, chrome: process.versions.chrome, node: process.versions.node }
        })
      - Avoid Node built-ins when sandbox: true (do not import fs/path).

6) Renderer: React Placeholder UI
   1. In src/renderer (React app entry), add a minimal page:
      - Show a title like "Factory Local App"
      - Buttons/labels to call window.api.ping() and display "pong" result.
      - Display versions from window.api.versions.
   2. Ensure TypeScript ambient types for window.api (create src/renderer/env.d.ts):
      - declare interface Window { api: { ping(): Promise<string>; versions: { electron: string; chrome: string; node: string } } }

7) TypeScript Configuration
   1. Root tsconfig.json:
      - "compilerOptions": { "target": "ES2020", "module": "ESNext", "strict": true, "moduleResolution": "Bundler", "jsx": "react-jsx", "types": ["node"] }
      - Include/Exclude appropriate src paths.
   2. If template splits tsconfig per package (main/preload/renderer), ensure each has strict: true and appropriate lib/module settings.

8) ESLint + Prettier Setup
   1. Install dev dependencies:
      - pnpm add -D eslint @typescript-eslint/parser @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin eslint-plugin-react eslint-plugin-react-hooks eslint-config-prettier prettier
   2. Create .eslintrc.cjs:
      module.exports = {
        root: true,
        env: { browser: true, node: true, es2021: true },
        parser: '@typescript-eslint/parser',
        parserOptions: { ecmaVersion: 'latest', sourceType: 'module', ecmaFeatures: { jsx: true } },
        plugins: ['@typescript-eslint', 'react', 'react-hooks'],
        extends: [
          'eslint:recommended',
          'plugin:@typescript-eslint/recommended',
          'plugin:react/recommended',
          'plugin:react-hooks/recommended',
          'prettier'
        ],
        settings: { react: { version: 'detect' } },
        rules: { 'react/react-in-jsx-scope': 'off' }
      }
   3. Create .prettierrc.json:
      { "semi": true, "singleQuote": true, "printWidth": 100, "trailingComma": "es5" }
   4. Add .prettierignore and .eslintignore (e.g., dist, out, build, node_modules).

9) Package Scripts (dev, build, lint, format)
   1. In package.json, ensure the following scripts exist/are adjusted:
      - "dev": "electron-vite dev"
      - "build": "electron-vite build && electron-builder"
      - "lint": "eslint . --ext .ts,.tsx,.cjs,.mjs"
      - "format": "prettier --write ."
   2. Keep "type": "module" if template uses ESM.

10) Electron Builder Configuration
   1. Add a minimal build config in package.json or electron-builder.yml:
      - appId: com.yourorg.factory-local-app
      - productName: Factory Local App
      - files: ["dist/**", "dist-electron/**", "package.json"] (paths may differ depending on template output)
      - directories: { output: "release" }
      - mac/win/linux targets: use defaults (e.g., dmg, nsis, AppImage) or minimal cross-platform.
   2. Ensure electron-builder is a devDependency (template usually includes it).

11) Content Security Policy (CSP)
   1. In renderer index.html, add a conservative CSP meta for production:
      - <meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="default-src 'self'; script-src 'self'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; img-src 'self' data:; connect-src 'self'; object-src 'none'; base-uri 'self'; form-action 'self'">
   2. For development, allow Vite's websocket: include ws://localhost:* in connect-src when NODE_ENV=development.

12) Test Dev Workflow
   1. Run: pnpm dev (or npm run dev)
   2. Verify the Electron window loads the React app, shows versions, and the ping button returns "pong".
   3. Confirm DevTools are available in dev and disabled in production builds.

13) Test Production Build
   1. Run: pnpm build (or npm run build)
   2. Verify artifacts are generated in release/ (or dist/ depending on template).
   3. Launch the packaged app to confirm it runs and shows the placeholder UI.

14) Documentation
   1. Create/Update README.md with:
      - Prerequisites
      - Install steps
      - Scripts (dev, build, lint, format)
      - Security defaults explanation (contextIsolation, sandbox, nodeIntegration=false, CSP)
      - Known paths for main/preload/renderer code
   2. Note how to switch between npm and pnpm.

Acceptance Checklist Mapping
- Run pnpm/npm run dev: opens Electron with React UI placeholder and working preload IPC (ping).
- Run pnpm/npm run build: produces a runnable packaged app.
- TypeScript config present (root and/or per package) with strict.
- ESLint + Prettier configured with scripts lint and format.
- Secure defaults in BrowserWindow: contextIsolation=true, sandbox=true, nodeIntegration=false; preload used; renderer sandboxed.
- Separate code packages for main, preload, renderer via electron-vite template.

features.title: Typed IPC contract and preload API surface
features.description: Define a minimal IPC contract with typed channels for: settings:get/set, project:select/validate, tasks:list, task:get, task:update, docs:list, docs:read, git:status, agents:list/start/stop/logs, llm:chat. Implement a preload script exposing a narrow, typed API to the renderer. Document IPC schemas in docs/ARCHITECTURE.md. Acceptance: TypeScript types for request/response payloads; runtime validation; renderer can call stubs for each channel; security validated (no Node APIs exposed directly).
features.plan:
Typed IPC contract and preload API surface – Implementation Plan

Goal
Provide a minimal, secure IPC contract with typed channels and runtime validation. Expose a narrow, typed preload API to the renderer. Include documentation and basic tests. Ensure no Node APIs are exposed.

Tech choices
- Language: TypeScript
- Validation: zod
- Electron APIs: ipcMain.handle / ipcRenderer.invoke, contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld
- Testing: vitest (or jest) for unit tests

1) Repository structure and dependencies
1.1. Create/confirm project structure:
- /electron/main/ (main process TS)
- /electron/preload/ (preload TS)
- /shared/ipc/ (shared channel names, schemas, types)
- /renderer/ (React code)
- /docs/ARCHITECTURE.md (IPC contract docs)
- /tests/ (unit tests for schemas and preload surface)
1.2. Add dependencies:
- dependencies: zod
- devDependencies: @types/electron, vitest (or jest), ts-node/tsup/esbuild as needed for build, typescript
1.3. Ensure tsconfig is split or configured for main/preload/renderer with isolatedModules.

2) Define channel names and IPC versioning
2.1. Create shared/ipc/channels.ts:
- export const IPC_VERSION = 'v1' as const
- export const Channels = {
  settings: { get: 'settings:get', set: 'settings:set' },
  project: { select: 'project:select', validate: 'project:validate' },
  tasks: { list: 'tasks:list', get: 'task:get', update: 'task:update' },
  docs: { list: 'docs:list', read: 'docs:read' },
  git: { status: 'git:status' },
  agents: { list: 'agents:list', start: 'agents:start', stop: 'agents:stop', logs: 'agents:logs' },
  llm: { chat: 'llm:chat' },
  meta: { version: 'ipc:version' }
} as const
- export type ChannelName = typeof Channels[keyof typeof Channels][keyof typeof Channels[keyof typeof Channels]]; (or flatten into a union)

3) Define runtime schemas and types
3.1. Create shared/ipc/schemas.ts using zod. For each channel define request/response schemas:
- settings:get
  Req: z.object({ keys: z.array(z.string()).optional() })
  Res: z.object({ values: z.record(z.unknown()) })
- settings:set
  Req: z.object({ values: z.record(z.unknown()) })
  Res: z.object({ success: z.boolean() })
- project:select
  Req: z.object({ path: z.string() })
  Res: z.object({ path: z.string(), name: z.string().optional(), valid: z.boolean() })
- project:validate
  Req: z.object({ path: z.string() })
  Res: z.object({ valid: z.boolean(), reasons: z.array(z.string()).optional() })
- tasks:list
  Req: z.object({ status: z.array(z.string()).optional(), search: z.string().optional(), limit: z.number().int().min(1).max(500).optional() })
  Res: z.object({ tasks: z.array(z.object({ id: z.string(), title: z.string(), status: z.string(), assignee: z.string().nullable().optional(), updatedAt: z.string() })) })
- task:get
  Req: z.object({ id: z.string() })
  Res: z.object({ id: z.string(), title: z.string(), description: z.string().optional(), status: z.string(), notes: z.string().optional(), metadata: z.record(z.unknown()).optional(), updatedAt: z.string() })
- task:update
  Req: z.object({ id: z.string(), patch: z.object({ title: z.string().optional(), description: z.string().optional(), status: z.string().optional(), notes: z.string().optional(), metadata: z.record(z.unknown()).optional() }).refine((p)=>Object.keys(p).length>0, 'patch must have at least 1 key') })
  Res: z.object({ success: z.boolean(), task: z.any().optional() })
- docs:list
  Req: z.object({ basePath: z.string().optional() })
  Res: z.object({ docs: z.array(z.object({ path: z.string(), title: z.string().optional() })) })
- docs:read
  Req: z.object({ path: z.string() })
  Res: z.object({ path: z.string(), content: z.string(), frontmatter: z.record(z.unknown()).optional() })
- git:status
  Req: z.object({ cwd: z.string().optional() })
  Res: z.object({ branch: z.string().optional(), dirty: z.boolean(), ahead: z.number().int().optional(), behind: z.number().int().optional(), files: z.array(z.object({ path: z.string(), status: z.string() })) })
- agents:list
  Req: z.object({})
  Res: z.object({ agents: z.array(z.object({ id: z.string(), name: z.string(), status: z.enum(['idle','running','stopped','error']), pid: z.number().optional(), taskId: z.string().optional() })) })
- agents:start
  Req: z.object({ id: z.string().optional(), name: z.string().optional(), args: z.record(z.unknown()).optional() }).refine((v)=>!!v.id||!!v.name, { message: 'id or name required' })
  Res: z.object({ success: z.boolean(), instanceId: z.string().optional() })
- agents:stop
  Req: z.object({ id: z.string() })
  Res: z.object({ success: z.boolean() })
- agents:logs
  Req: z.object({ id: z.string(), since: z.number().int().optional(), limit: z.number().int().optional() })
  Res: z.object({ logs: z.array(z.object({ ts: z.number(), level: z.enum(['debug','info','warn','error']), message: z.string() })) })
- llm:chat
  Req: z.object({ model: z.string().optional(), messages: z.array(z.object({ role: z.enum(['system','user','assistant','tool']), content: z.string(), name: z.string().optional(), tool_call_id: z.string().optional() })), temperature: z.number().min(0).max(2).optional() })
  Res: z.object({ message: z.object({ role: z.literal('assistant'), content: z.string() }), usage: z.object({ promptTokens: z.number().optional(), completionTokens: z.number().optional() }).optional() })
- meta: version
  Req: z.object({}) ; Res: z.object({ version: z.string() })
3.2. Create shared/ipc/types.ts exporting TypeScript types via zod.infer for all request/response payloads (e.g., SettingsGetReq = z.infer<typeof Schemas.Settings.Get.Req>) and grouped namespaces.

4) Main-process: typed handler registration with runtime validation
4.1. Create electron/main/ipc/handle.ts with helper:
- function registerHandler<TReq, TRes>(channel: string, reqSchema: ZodSchema<TReq>, resSchema: ZodSchema<TRes>, handler: (event, req: TReq) => Promise<TRes> | TRes)
  - ipcMain.handle(channel, async (event, raw) => { const req = reqSchema.parse(raw); const res = await handler(event, req); return resSchema.parse(res); })
4.2. Create electron/main/ipc/register.ts to register all channels with stub handlers:
- settings:get -> in-memory store (Map) returning requested keys or all
- settings:set -> merge into Map, return { success: true }
- project:select -> return { path, name: basename(path), valid: true }
- project:validate -> return { valid: true, reasons: [] }
- tasks:list -> return { tasks: [] } (stub)
- task:get -> return a fabricated task for given id
- task:update -> noop update against fabricated task; return { success: true, task: { ... } }
- docs:list -> return { docs: [{ path: 'README.md', title: 'README' }] }
- docs:read -> return content stub like '# Placeholder'
- git:status -> return { dirty: false, files: [], branch: 'main', ahead: 0, behind: 0 }
- agents:list -> return an empty list
- agents:start -> return { success: true, instanceId: 'stub-1' }
- agents:stop -> return { success: true }
- agents:logs -> return { logs: [] }
- llm:chat -> return { message: { role: 'assistant', content: 'Stub response' } }
- ipc:version -> return { version: IPC_VERSION }
4.3. Wire registration in electron/main/index.ts after app.whenReady():
- import registerIPCHandlers() and call it before creating BrowserWindow

5) Preload: secure, narrow, typed API surface
5.1. Create electron/preload/safeInvoke.ts
- function safeInvoke<TReq, TRes>(channel, reqSchema, resSchema, payload):
  - validate payload with reqSchema.parse
  - const res = await ipcRenderer.invoke(channel, payload)
  - return resSchema.parse(res)
5.2. Create electron/preload/index.ts
- Use contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld('api', {
  meta: { version: () => safeInvoke(Channels.meta.version, Schemas.Meta.Version.Req, Schemas.Meta.Version.Res, {}) },
  settings: { get: (keys?) => safeInvoke(...), set: (values) => safeInvoke(...) },
  project: { select: (path) => safeInvoke(...), validate: (path) => safeInvoke(...) },
  tasks: { list: (opts?) => safeInvoke(...), get: (id) => safeInvoke(...), update: (id, patch) => safeInvoke(...) },
  docs: { list: (basePath?) => safeInvoke(...), read: (path) => safeInvoke(...) },
  git: { status: (cwd?) => safeInvoke(...) },
  agents: { list: () => safeInvoke(...), start: (args) => safeInvoke(...), stop: (id) => safeInvoke(...), logs: (id, opts?) => safeInvoke(...) },
  llm: { chat: (input) => safeInvoke(...) }
})
5.3. Add electron/preload/global.d.ts to augment Window:
- declare global { interface Window { api: { ...full typed surface... } } }
5.4. Ensure no Node APIs are exposed; do not export ipcRenderer or fs. Only functions above.

6) BrowserWindow security hardening
6.1. In electron/main/createWindow.ts (or index.ts) when creating BrowserWindow:
- webPreferences: {
  contextIsolation: true,
  nodeIntegration: false,
  enableRemoteModule: false,
  sandbox: true,
  preload: path.join(__dirname, 'preload.js'),
}
- Set a Content Security Policy for the renderer (meta tag or headers if using custom protocol). Disallow eval.
- Validate allowed origins if loading external content (prefer file:// or custom app:// protocol only).

7) Renderer stubs/smoke wiring
7.1. In renderer, create a simple hook or effect that calls window.api.meta.version() and window.api.tasks.list() and logs results to ensure stubs function.
7.2. Add minimal UI trigger (button) to call, but feature acceptance only requires renderer can call stubs; the hook suffices.

8) Tests
8.1. Schema tests (tests/ipc.schemas.test.ts):
- For each Req/Res schema, test valid payload passes and representative invalid payload fails.
8.2. Preload API surface tests (tests/preload.api.test.ts):
- Mock ipcRenderer.invoke and assert safeInvoke parses/throws correctly.
- Assert window.api exposes only expected top-level keys (Object.keys(window.api)).
8.3. Handler tests (tests/main.handlers.test.ts):
- Unit test registerHandler rejects invalid requests and validates responses.

9) Documentation
9.1. Create/extend docs/ARCHITECTURE.md with:
- IPC overview: goals, security model, versioning (IPC_VERSION = v1), channel naming conventions, request/response flow.
- Channel catalog: list each channel with request/response shape (brief tables or bullet lists), example payloads, error semantics (Zod errors mapped to { code: 'BAD_REQUEST', message }).
- Preload API surface: document window.api structure and usage examples.
- Security posture: contextIsolation, nodeIntegration=false, no Node exposure, runtime validation, CSP.
- Extensibility: how to add a new channel (add schemas, types, handler, preload function, docs), versioning strategy (introduce v2 channels or feature-detect via ipc:version).

10) DX and linting safeguards
10.1. Add ESLint/TS rules to prevent importing 'electron' or Node built-ins in /renderer.
10.2. Add tsconfig path aliases: '@shared/*' -> './shared/*' to share types.
10.3. Add a precommit hook to run type check and tests for IPC layers.

11) Acceptance validation checklist
- TypeScript types exported for all request/response payloads under shared/ipc/types.ts
- All ipcMain handlers and preload wrappers validate with zod at runtime
- Renderer can call stubs for each channel: add a simple smoke call on app start
- Security validated: BrowserWindow uses contextIsolation, nodeIntegration=false, sandbox=true; preload exposes only window.api; no direct Node APIs accessible in renderer

12) Future work hooks (non-blocking)
- Swap stub handlers with real integrations (git CLI, agents orchestrator, docs FS)
- Introduce structured error type and map zod errors to renderer-friendly error codes
- Add streaming support for llm:chat (via ipc event or MessagePort)
- Add permissions model to restrict llm:chat to read-only tools

features.title: Local settings storage and project root selector
features.description: Implement a JSON-backed settings store in Electron userData path. Create UI to set and persist the path to the factory project root. Implement project validation against docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md (check tasks/, docs/, scripts/, etc.). Acceptance: User can pick a folder; app validates and persists; invalid structure yields clear error; settings survive restarts; tested on macOS/Windows/Linux paths.
features.plan:
Title: Local settings storage and project root selector (Electron + React)

Goal
- Persist user settings (JSON) in Electron app.getPath('userData')
- Provide UI to pick and persist the factory project root directory
- Validate the selected project directory against required structure (including docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md and key folders like tasks/, docs/, scripts/)
- Show clear errors for invalid selections
- Ensure settings survive restarts
- Work on macOS, Windows, Linux

High-level Architecture
- Main process: SettingsStore (JSON on disk), ProjectValidator (filesystem checks), IPC handlers for settings and validation
- Preload: Expose a minimal, typed API via contextBridge
- Renderer: Settings UI (React) to view/change project root, invoke validation, and show status
- Shared types: TS interfaces for Settings and ValidationResult used across boundaries

Step-by-step Plan
1) Define shared types
   - Create src/shared/types.ts:
     - export interface AppSettings { version: number; projectRootPath?: string; lastValidatedAt?: string; }
     - export interface ValidationIssue { code: string; message: string; path?: string; }
     - export interface ValidationResult { ok: boolean; issues: ValidationIssue[]; }

2) Implement SettingsStore in main
   - File: src/main/settings/SettingsStore.ts
   - Responsibilities:
     - Use app.getPath('userData') to determine settings path (e.g., settings.json)
     - Load on construction; if file missing, start with defaults { version: 1 }
     - Provide async get(): Promise<AppSettings>
     - Provide async set(patch: Partial<AppSettings>): Promise<AppSettings>
     - Atomic write approach: write to temp file then rename, or writeFile with fs.promises; include try/catch and fallback
     - Validate JSON on read; if corrupted, back up to settings.bak-<timestamp>.json and reset to defaults
     - Normalize stored paths (use path.resolve and path.normalize), preserve original case on Windows but normalize separators in logic
     - Export a singleton instance

3) Implement ProjectValidator in main
   - File: src/main/validation/ProjectValidator.ts
   - validate(path: string): Promise<ValidationResult>
     - Steps:
       a) Resolve and realpath the provided path; ensure it exists and is a directory -> else issues.push({ code: 'NOT_A_DIRECTORY', ... })
       b) Check required items:
          - docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md exists
          - tasks/ directory exists
          - docs/ directory exists
          - scripts/ directory exists
       c) Optional checks (non-blocking warnings): .git exists; README.md exists
       d) If docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md exists, optionally parse for additional expected paths:
          - Simple heuristic: scan for backticked paths or lines starting with - or * that contain folder names; for each "path/" token, check existence; add issues with code 'MISSING_FROM_DOCS_SPEC' if missing (as warning)
       e) Accumulate issues; ok = issues with blocking codes length === 0
       f) Return { ok, issues }
     - Cross-platform notes: use path.join; avoid hard-coded separators; handle permissions by catching EACCES and reporting code 'PERMISSION_DENIED'

4) IPC contract and handlers (main)
   - File: src/main/ipc/settingsIpc.ts
   - Register in app ready phase
   - ipcMain.handle('settings:get', async () => SettingsStore.get())
   - ipcMain.handle('settings:setProjectRoot', async (event, folderPath: string) => {
       const result = await ProjectValidator.validate(folderPath)
       if (!result.ok) return { ok: false, result }
       const settings = await SettingsStore.set({ projectRootPath: path.resolve(folderPath), lastValidatedAt: new Date().toISOString() })
       return { ok: true, settings, result }
     })
   - ipcMain.handle('settings:validateProjectRoot', async (event, folderPath: string) => {
       return await ProjectValidator.validate(folderPath)
     })

5) Preload bridge
   - File: src/preload/index.ts
   - contextIsolation: true, nodeIntegration: false
   - Expose api.settings with types:
     - get(): Promise<AppSettings>
     - setProjectRoot(path: string): Promise<{ ok: boolean; settings?: AppSettings; result: ValidationResult }>
     - validateProjectRoot(path: string): Promise<ValidationResult>
   - Use ipcRenderer.invoke for the above channels

6) Renderer: Settings UI
   - Files:
     - src/renderer/pages/Settings.tsx
     - src/renderer/components/FolderPicker.tsx
   - Settings.tsx features:
     - Load current settings on mount (api.settings.get)
     - Show current projectRootPath (read-only field or text)
     - Input + "Browse" button to open folder dialog (via a small main-side helper or use ipcRenderer.invoke('dialog:openDirectory'))
       - Add a minimal dialog handler in main: ipcMain.handle('dialog:openDirectory', async () => dialog.showOpenDialog({ properties: ['openDirectory'] }))
     - Validate button: calls api.settings.validateProjectRoot(path)
     - Save button: calls api.settings.setProjectRoot(path)
     - Status area:
       - If validation ok: green success message
       - If invalid: list issues with clear messages and codes; group blocking vs warnings
     - Clear/Reset button: let user clear projectRootPath (api.settings.setProjectRoot('')) or add 'settings:clear' handler to remove the key
   - FolderPicker.tsx: simple component with input and Browse button

7) App startup behavior
   - In main app ready:
     - Load settings; if no projectRootPath or validation fails (validate on startup), consider presenting a modal or route to Settings page in renderer
   - In renderer root, if settings.projectRootPath missing or invalid, redirect to Settings route

8) Error handling and messaging
   - Translate ValidationIssue codes to user-friendly text in UI:
     - NOT_A_DIRECTORY: "Selected path is not a directory or does not exist"
     - MISSING_FILE_ORGANISATION: "Missing docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md"
     - MISSING_TASKS_DIR: "Missing tasks/ folder"
     - MISSING_DOCS_DIR: "Missing docs/ folder"
     - MISSING_SCRIPTS_DIR: "Missing scripts/ folder"
     - PERMISSION_DENIED: "Insufficient permissions to read this path"
     - MISSING_FROM_DOCS_SPEC: "Path referenced in FILE_ORGANISATION.md not found"
   - The API returns structured issues; the UI shows them clearly

9) Cross-platform considerations
   - Use path.join and fs.promises
   - Avoid shell expansions; always resolve absolute paths
   - Windows: handle drive letters; do not alter case; store as returned by dialog
   - Linux/macOS: follow symlinks via fs.realpath; but store the user-chosen path and keep resolved path only for internal checks
   - Dialog filters: none (directory only)

10) Persistence verification
   - Ensure settings.json written to app.getPath('userData')
   - On restart, SettingsStore loads existing file and hydrates state
   - Add logging in dev for load/save paths

11) Testing
   - Unit tests (Node/Vitest or Jest) for ProjectValidator:
     - Valid structure returns ok=true
     - Missing tasks/ -> blocking issue
     - Missing docs/FILE_ORGANISATION.md -> blocking issue
     - Permission denied (simulate by pointing to a restricted dir) -> PERMISSION_DENIED
     - Cross-platform path normalization tests (use path.normalize) and mock fs where needed
   - Manual E2E checks on macOS/Windows/Linux:
     - Pick valid project root -> success and persisted across app restart
     - Pick invalid folder -> clear errors shown, not persisted
     - After save, restart app -> settings loaded, UI shows selected path

12) Implementation details and scaffolding
   - Add new scripts/entries:
     - Ensure preload is configured in BrowserWindow({ webPreferences: { preload, contextIsolation: true, nodeIntegration: false } })
   - Update TypeScript config to include src/shared in both main and renderer tsconfig references
   - Add minimal logging facility for main (console in dev)

13) Documentation
   - Add docs/settings.md explaining persistence location per OS, what is validated, and troubleshooting common errors
   - Update README to describe how to configure project root in the app

14) Acceptance criteria mapping
   - User can pick a folder: Settings UI with folder dialog
   - App validates and persists: 'Validate' and 'Save' flows wire to ProjectValidator and SettingsStore
   - Invalid structure yields clear error: ValidationIssue codes/messages shown in UI
   - Settings survive restarts: stored in userData/settings.json and loaded on launch
   - Tested on macOS/Windows/Linux: unit tests + manual steps documented

15) Nice-to-haves (deferred if time-limited)
   - Live watcher: revalidate when project structure changes
   - Auto-detect probable project root by scanning parent folders for matching structure
   - Migration system for settings.version

features.title: Task schema definition and validator
features.description: Create a JSON Schema that mirrors the canonical task format described in docs/tasks/task_format.py and task_example.json. Generate TypeScript interfaces from the schema. Implement a validator used before reading/writing task.json. Acceptance: Validator catches malformed examples; TS types aligned with schema; unit tests cover valid/invalid cases using sample task.json files.

features.title: Tasks indexer and file watcher
features.description: Scan tasks/{id}/ directories under the selected project root to build an in-memory index of tasks and features. Implement a file watcher to refresh the index on changes (create/modify/delete). Cache results for quick UI rendering. Acceptance: Indexing handles 100+ tasks; watcher reliably updates on file changes; performance measured and documented; exposed via IPC: tasks:list and task:get.

features.title: Tasks list UI with filtering and search
features.description: Build a React view listing tasks with id, title, status, and counts of features (done/total). Provide text search and filters (e.g., status). Clicking a row opens details. Acceptance: Renders list from IPC data; filtering/search applied client-side; empty states handled; accessibility basics (labels, keyboard nav) covered.

features.title: Task details view with feature list and editing notes/fields
features.description: Create a detail page showing the task metadata and its features with statuses. Implement controlled editing for permitted fields (e.g., description, notes, status) with schema validation and disk write-back via task:update IPC. Provide change preview and basic error handling. Acceptance: Edits persist to task.json on disk, schema-valid; changes reflected in UI and index; guard rails prevent schema-breaking updates; unit/e2e tests simulate common edits.

features.title: Markdown documentation explorer and renderer
features.description: Implement a docs browser that lists Markdown files under docs/ (including docs/tasks/*). Render Markdown with basic extensions (tables, code highlighting), safe HTML sanitization, and internal link navigation. Acceptance: Sidebar shows directory tree; renderer supports anchors and code blocks; clicking internal links navigates within the app; large files render efficiently; tested with provided docs/*.md.

features.title: Read-only Git status panel
features.description: Expose project Git status via IPC by invoking the git CLI or a lightweight library. Show current branch, ahead/behind, changed files, and submodule summary. No write operations from this panel. Acceptance: Works across platforms; handles repositories with submodules; performance acceptable; unit tests stub git outputs; UI displays clear status indicators.

features.title: Agent process manager (start/stop/list, logs)
features.description: Implement process orchestration to run local agents via scripts/run_local_agent.py (or equivalent). Configurable Python interpreter path. Provide UI to start/stop agents, view running processes, and stream stdout/stderr logs with persistence. Acceptance: Start/stop works with sample agent; logs stream and are saved to file; broken interpreter path yields clear error; protected from multiple accidental starts; IPC: agents:list/start/stop/logs implemented.

features.title: Agent activity detection and completion notifications
features.description: Detect agent progress by monitoring process lifecycle and file changes in tasks/ (e.g., updated task.json or tests). When an agent finishes or triggers notable changes, show OS notifications and add to an in-app notifications center. Acceptance: File watcher identifies relevant changes; notification includes agent name and summary; user can mute/disable; tested with simulated runs; no duplicate spam.

features.title: Notifications center UI and preferences
features.description: Add a notifications panel listing recent events (agent started/stopped, edits saved, git changes). Provide settings to enable/disable OS notifications and categories. Acceptance: Notifications persist across reloads; can be marked as read; preferences stored in settings; OS notifications use Electron Notification with fallbacks.

features.title: Chat interface UI (sessions, messages, basic send/receive)
features.description: Create a chat UI with session list, message view, composer with multiline input, and send action. Persist conversation locally. Pluggable model selector. Acceptance: New session, rename session, message history persists; keyboard shortcuts (Shift+Enter for newline, Enter to send configurable); empty/error states handled; uses llm:chat IPC stub.

features.title: LLM connector abstraction and providers (LiteLLM, OpenAI-compatible)
features.description: Design an abstraction for chat providers. Implement connectors for: (1) LiteLLM-compatible HTTP endpoint, (2) OpenAI-compatible custom base URL to support LM Studio / Ollama. Configurable API key, base URL, model name, timeouts. Acceptance: Provider interface documented; connectors unit-tested with mocked servers; UI to add/edit providers; failing requests produce actionable errors.

features.title: Read-only tool adapters for chat
features.description: Implement tools accessible from chat with strict read-only capabilities: read_file, list_dir (scoped to project root), docs_index, read_doc, tasks_index, get_task, git_status, list_agents, agent_log_tail. Enforce allowlists and path sandboxing. Acceptance: Tools cannot write to disk; attempts to escape sandbox blocked; usage audited/logged; tool registry exposes metadata; covered by security unit tests.

features.title: Chat tool permissions and admin gating
features.description: Add UI and backend enforcement for enabling/disabling tools per session. Provide a clear indicator in the chat UI of which tools are enabled. Acceptance: Disabled tools are not invocable; permissions persist; attempting to call a disabled tool returns a controlled error; tests verify enforcement at IPC and provider levels.

features.title: Context retrieval for chat (RAG-lite)
features.description: Implement simple keyword-based search over project docs and tasks. Allow user to attach retrieved snippets into context before sending. Optionally auto-attach top-k snippets with a toggle. Acceptance: Search returns ranked results quickly; selected snippets previewed; tokens limited by model configuration; unit tests confirm deterministic retrieval on fixed corpora.

features.title: Child projects overview (submodules browser)
features.description: List submodules under projects/ with name, URL, current commit, and dirty status. Provide quick links to open in file explorer or terminal. Acceptance: Handles absent submodules gracefully; data sourced via git plumbing; UI updates when submodule pointers change; read-only operations only.

features.title: Cross-platform packaging configuration
features.description: Configure electron-builder to produce distributables for macOS (dmg), Windows (nsis), and Linux (AppImage). Include app icons and code signing placeholders. Acceptance: CI-local builds produce artifacts; metadata correct (name, version, copyright); app auto-updates disabled initially.

features.title: CI pipeline for build and release
features.description: Add GitHub Actions workflows to lint, type-check, build, and produce release artifacts on tags. Cache dependencies for speed. Optionally draft release with artifacts attached. Acceptance: CI green on main; tag push triggers build for all OS targets; artifacts downloadable; secrets managed securely (no plaintext keys).

features.title: Developer documentation and runbook
features.description: Complete docs: ARCHITECTURE.md (process boundaries, IPC contract), DEVELOPMENT.md (setup, scripts), SECURITY.md (IPC, sandbox, tool restrictions), PROVIDERS.md (LLM connectors), AGENTS.md (how agent processes are managed), and a quickstart. Acceptance: Docs pass link check; examples tested; contributors can set up locally following docs without assistance.
